results.title: The ‘Hard Hat Riot’ Was a Preview of Today’s Political Divisions
results.abstract: Mayor Lindsay saw a country “virtually on the edge of a spiritual — and perhaps even a physical — breakdown.”
org_facet: American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations

multimedia.caption: On May 8, 1970, construction workers violently disrupted a peaceful demonstration on Wall Street before marching to City Hall and Pace College. The event became known as the “Hard Hat Riot.”

results.title: Study Offers Details of U.S. Children Severely Sickened by Coronavirus
results.abstract: Most of the 48 I.C.U. patients studied had pre-existing medical conditions, including two who died. Eighteen of the children were put on ventilators.

results.title: Barbara Babcock, Stanford’s First Female Law Professor, Dies at 81
results.abstract: She helped Ruth Bader Ginsburg win a federal judgeship. “I would not hold the good job I have today were it not for Barbara,” Justice Ginsburg said.

multimedia.caption: Barbara Babcock in 2010. She helped Jimmy Carter appoint more women and minorities to the federal bench than all previous presidents combined.

results.title: Three Weeks in April: An E.M.T. Crew Faces Exhaustion, Isolation and Death
results.abstract: A photojournalist switched careers and became an E.M.T. just months before the coronavirus pandemic hit. Recently, he brought his camera along to document what he and his crew are seeing.

multimedia.caption: Emergency medical technicians, or E.M.T.s, carried a man in cardiac arrest out of his home in Yonkers, N.Y., earlier this month. He had shown symptoms of Covid-19 before medical staff arrived; he later died at the hospital.

results.title: Eating in Xi’an, Where Wheat and Lamb Speak to China’s Varied Palette
results.abstract: In the city’s Muslim Quarter, meals are a celebration of globalization and ethnic diversity — and a lasting defense against erasure.

multimedia.caption: A dumpling steamer outside one of the shops in the Muslim district of Xi’an in central China, where locally cultivated wheat — once foreign to the country — is now crucial in the preparation of dumplings, noodles and bread.

results.title: In Uzbekistan, Coming to Terms With the Country’s Dazzling History
results.abstract: Central Asia was once home to several bustling trade cities. Today, traveling through them reawakens a distant, though not forgotten, past.

multimedia.caption: The prayer hall of the late 18th-century Juma Mosque in Khiva. Its design — which features more than 200 elm or other wood columns, over two dozen of which date back to either the 10th or 16th century — differs from those of most open-air mosques of the region, creating a more secluded environment for worship.
